Context: This Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care program is delivered online with a virtual learning environment, allowing flexibility for working professionals. The program can be completed full-time over two semesters or part-time. Students will develop skills in interprofessional teamwork, evidence-based care planning, identifying age-related changes, assessing and responding to client health conditions, and studying principles of interprofessional, relational, and end-of-life care. The clinical placement component requires 120 hours for graduation, which can be completed with an existing employer in the long-term care sector or through a virtual clinical placement experience if seeking a career change. Students will earn college and university course credits. Some clinical or work placements may require proof of full vaccination and PPE.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care Program (Postgraduate) S417 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The George Brown College offers an Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care (S417) program, which is an Ontario College Graduate Certificate. Upon graduation from this program, students will be prepared for roles as coordinators or managers in various health-care facilities such as long-term care homes, retirement homes, complex continuing care, rehabilitation, home health services, home visiting health services, seniors' day services, hospitals, and other healthcare organizations. The skills developed from this program are in demand in institutional settings where interprofessional care knowledge and expertise are required. This program offers laddering opportunities into additional certificate and diploma programs, and learners will gain transferable skills and credits toward other programs like baccalaureate degrees in nursing, health sciences management or gerontology. The academic pathways available upon graduation include the opportunity to apply for advanced standing for two credits in an undergraduate degree at Toronto Metropolitan University. The program consists of semester 1 and semester 2, with required courses such as Introduction to Gerontology, Interprofessional Education and Care, Communication, Coordination of Dementia Care, Complex and Long-Term Care, and Capstone Field Placement. The instruction methods for these courses are online.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care Program (Postgraduate) S417 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Program Learning Outcomes:
- Upon completion of the program, the graduate will be able to advocate for client care plans as a member of an interprofessional team.
- Communicate with clients, family members and health-care professionals to promote relational care and strengthen interprofessional collaborative practice.
- Manage changes in client’s ability to interact with their environment to provide support to client and family care needs.
- Support long-term client care and quality of life within complex social, economic, legal and political systems.
- Manage changes in client conditions through the use of evidence-informed approaches, tools and techniques to identify and address client health.
- Integrate principles and philosophy of end of life (EOL) care to support clients and their families in complex and long-term care settings.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $4,872.00 for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022.
- Financial Assistance: The program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet OSAP eligibility criteria.

Admission Requirements:
- Any health-related bachelor's degree, college-level diploma or certificate, health-related pathway program OR equivalent work experience.
- Required documents: official transcripts and proof of credential. For applicants applying based on work experience only, an endorsement, special portfolio, resumé and references are required. International documents must be evaluated by ICAS/WES.

Transfer Credits:
- College or university credits may qualify for transfer.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care Program (Postgraduate) S417 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text mentions a certificate program related to activation coordinators or gerontologists. Here are the key facts extracted from the text:

1. Students can transfer up to 75% of previously completed courses (within the past three years) towards the certificate.
2. Upon acceptance into the program, students must meet and complete mandatory pre-placement requirements, including submitting medical records, police checks, and certifications.
3. The health policies and non-academic requirements are designed to protect clients and vulnerable populations that students will engage in practice with.
4. Students who do not comply with the program’s health policy and non-academic requirements or submit all required documentation by deadlines may be excluded from clinical practicum, which could jeopardize academic standing and completion of the program.
5. The overall costs, service fees, and fines associated with the health requirements are the responsibility of the student.
6. Students must have a Police Vulnerable Sector Check completed and renewed annually before entering into field or clinical placement. The process typically takes two to three months but can take up to eight months under some circumstances.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care Program (Postgraduate) S417 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: Students are required to obtain a Police Vulnerable Sector Check for working with vulnerable persons in their field or clinical placements at George Brown College. Those unable to provide a "clear" check will not be able to complete the program, and may jeopardize their progress. The fees for the police record check vary, and domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. Contact information for the Sally Horsfall Eaton School of Nursing is provided, along with details on related programs including Practical Nursing (PN), Bachelor of Science in Nursing (B.Sc.N.), RPN Bridge to BScN (Postgraduate), and Ontario College Graduate Certificate. Prospective students can book a campus tour or info session, and sign up for tailored resources to aid in their application process. Students must have JavaScript enabled to use the application form. The application requires the student's first name, last name, email address, domestic or international status, and country of origin. They must also agree to receive email communications from George Brown College.
